resources.string: How to show a location in other map app
Share the location from your map app or web browser.
Screenshot of Google Maps’ share screen
Choose %1$s and %2$s will let you open the location in any installed map app.
Configure Android to open links to Google Maps in alternative maps (optional)
First, go to Settings → Apps → Maps → Open by default and turn off the opening of links in this app.
Screenshot of Google Maps’ Open by default settings
Then go to Settings → Apps → %1$s → Open by default, turn on the opening of links in this app, and tap Add links.
Screenshot of %1$s’s Open by default settings

Select at least <tt>maps.google.com</tt> and <tt>maps.app.goo.gl</tt>. If some links are grayed out, other Google apps are set to open them by default. You can find these apps and turn off the opening of links for them, like we did for Google Maps.
Select %1$s when sharing a location from your map app.
Screenshot of Google Maps’ share screen
Or open %1$s and paste your map link there.
%1s supports many Google Maps, Apple Maps… URL formats. If you still find a link that doesn’t work, please report an issue.
The link <tt>%1$s</tt> doesn’t contain coordinates or place name. %2$s needs to connect to the map service to get the information.
The link <tt>%1$s</tt> doesn’t contain coordinates, but it contains a place name. %2$s can connect to the map service to get the coordinates, or it can use the place name, which is less precise.
To let %1$s open other map apps, you need to allow Other permissions → Display pop-up windows while running in the background to %1$s.

%1$s is a free and open-source app distributed under the GPL 3.0 or later license.


You can find the code at GitHub, where you can also report issues.


Your feedback is welcome. You can reach me at jakub@jakubvalenta.cz.
How it works and privacy considerations

%1$s converts map links into geo: links that can be opened by other map apps. To create a geo: link, geographic coordinates are required. %1$s extracts them from the map URL.


However, not all map URLs include coordinates. In such cases, %1$s will prompt you for permission to connect to the map service (Google Maps, Apple Maps etc.) and retrieve the coordinates from either HTTP headers or the HTML document of the link.


More precisely, there are three scenarios how %1$s converts a map URL into a geo: URI:


1.


If the map URL already contains geographic coordinates (for example https://www.google.com/maps/place/Central+Park/data=!3d44.4490541!4d26.0888398), then it’s parsed and no request to the map service’s servers is made.


2.


If the map URL doesn’t contain geographic coordinates (for example https://www.google.com/maps/place/Central+Park/), then %1$s asks you if it can connect to the map service.


If you allow connecting to the map service, then %1$s makes an HTTP GET request to Google Maps (or Apple Maps etc.) and parses the coordinates from the HTML response. You can imagine it as curl https://www.google.com/maps/place/Central+Park/ | grep -E \'/@[0-9.,-]+\'.


If you don’t allow connecting to the map service, then %1$s creates a geo: link with a place search term (for example geo:0,0?q=Central%%20Park).


3.


If the map URL is a short link (for example https://maps.app.goo.gl/TmbeHMiLEfTBws9EA), then %1$s asks you if it can connect to the map service.


If you allow connecting to the map service, then %1$s makes an HTTP HEAD request to the short link and reads the full link from the response headers. You can imagine it as curl -I https://maps.app.goo.gl/TmbeHMiLEfTBws9EA | grep location:. Then %1$s continues with scenario 1 or 2, depending on whether the full link contains coordinates or not. In case of scenario 2, another connection to the map service will be made, but this time without asking.


If you don’t allow connecting to the map service, then %1$s cancels the creation of the geo: link.



To permanently allow or deny connecting to the map service instead of always asking (the default), go to the app’s Preferences.
Compatibility with the GMaps WV app
You don’t need %1$s when using the GMaps WV app, because that app already produces geo: links. So you can directly share a location from GMaps WV with another map app.
Allow connecting to map service (Google, Apple etc.)?
To support short map links, and to get coordinates from the map app web page when the link doesn’t contain them, %1$s can connect to the map service. You can find more information on the FAQ screen.
Which version of the app was last run?
Connection error when resolving short link
Can’t open other map apps without permission
No app that can open map links is installed
This link is not supported without connecting to the map service
Failed to fetch page from the map service
Connection error when fetching page from the map service
